Thank you for your comment.  Actually, red-green color blindness is considered both an example of X-linked recessive genetic disorder and sex linkage.  The gene for color blindness is located on the X chromosome, making it a sex-linked trait.  Additionally, the inheritance pattern follows an X-linked recessive pattern, where males are more likely to be affected due to having only one X chromosome. Females can also be affected if they inherit two copies of the recessive allele. If you have any further questions or would like more information, I'm happy to help clarify.

Hello! Thank you for your comment. We appreciate your feedback. The content of this playlist has been designed to align with the syllabus outline of the Cambridge IGCSE Biology Paper (Paper 0610) by Cambridge Assessment International Education, specifically for exams in 2023, 2024, and 2025.   If there are specific details or topics from this curriculum that you believe are missing, please feel free to share them with us. We will certainly take your input into consideration.
Apologies, could you please provide more information? Thank you!
@IGCSEStudyBuddy  srry actually it is a *why not what

If the unknown allele is dominant (two copies of the dominant allele), then when crossed with a homozygous recessive individual, all the offspring will show the dominant trait.  If the unknown allele is recessive (one copy of the dominant allele and one copy of the recessive allele), then when crossed with a homozygous recessive individual, all the offspring will show the recessive trait.

By crossing the unknown allele with a homozygous recessive individual, you create a controlled situation where the only possible alleles in the offspring are the unknown allele and the recessive allele. This simplifies the analysis and allows for a clearer determination of whether the unknown allele is dominant or recessive based on the observed traits in the offspring.
